title: 113_s743
content: The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" authorizes the collection of sales and use taxes. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" authorizes Member States under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement to require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales. Non-Member States can also require sellers to collect taxes, regardless of other laws. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows states to mandate sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales, contingent on meeting minimum simplification requirements. This authority can be exercised no earlier than six months after the state enacts legislation specifying the applicable taxes and products/services. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows states to mandate sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales. States must meet minimum simplification requirements, including a single entity for tax administration, audits, and return processing for remote sales sourced to the state. Remote sellers cannot be required to file tax returns more frequently than nonremote sellers or face additional tax collection requirements. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates remote sellers to collect and remit sales taxes. States must simplify tax requirements and provide uniform tax bases. Remote sellers must source all sales correctly and receive software to calculate taxes on transactions. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates remote sellers to use certified software providers for calculating and filing sales and use taxes in all qualified States. Certified software providers are relieved from liability for errors, and remote sellers are not liable for incorrect tax collection if using certified software providers. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates the use of certified software providers for tax calculations. These providers are not liable for errors, and remote sellers are not responsible for incorrect tax collection if using certified software. Remote sellers and providers are also protected from liability for incorrect information provided by the State. Additionally, they must be given 90 days notice of any tax rate changes. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" requires certified software providers for tax calculations, protecting them from errors. Remote sellers are not liable for incorrect tax collection when using certified software. They must be given 90 days notice of any tax rate changes. States can only require remote sellers to collect taxes if their total remote sales exceed $1,000,000 in the previous year. Gross annual receipts from remote sales of related persons can be aggregated to meet the threshold. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 prohibits ownership relationships designed to avoid tax rules. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 prohibits ownership relationships designed to avoid tax rules. Limitations are outlined in Section 3. The Act clarifies that it does not subject sellers to various taxes other than sales and use taxes, does not affect tax application or state authority, does not create nexus, allows sellers to choose software providers, and does not impact licensing, regulatory requirements, or interstate commerce matters. The Act clarifies that it does not encourage new taxes on products or services not previously taxed, applies only to remote sales, and does not affect intrastate sales or the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. In this Act, definitions include terms like "certified software provider," "locality," "Member State," "person," and "remote sale." The Act defines terms such as "remote sale" as a sale into a State where the seller is not required to pay sales taxes, "remote seller" as a person making remote sales, and "sourced" as the location where the product is received by the purchaser. The Act defines terms related to remote sales and sourcing, including the definition of a "State" and the requirements for compliance with the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The "Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement" refers to the multi-State agreement adopted on November 12, 2002, and amended periodically. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. SEC. 6. PREEMPTION. This Act does not preempt State or local jurisdiction powers, except as specified.
